label.text: Microplastics and Marine Organisms
Plastic particles that are smaller than 5 millimetres in diameter are classified as microplastics.
Most microplastics come from larger pieces of plastic that age and break into smaller fragments.

The use of plastics in bottles, packaging and bags has led to the accumulation (build-up) of large amounts of microplastics in the environment. This is a problem because microplastics do not easily decompose.
Microplastics do not dissolve in water and are less dense than water.
Microplastics can accumulate (buildup) in the cells and tissues of marine organisms.
The major source of the microplastics that accumulate in these organisms is the food they eat.
Which one of the following statements must be true for microplastics to accumulate in a marine organism?
The microplastics must resemble the organism’s natural food.
The microplastics must be present in every item of food eaten by the organism.
The microplastics must be removed from the organism’s body more slowly than they are ingested.
The microplastics must have originated from discarded single-use plastics, such as plastic drinking straws.
Amara is concerned about the amount of microplastics in the environment. As a result of her concern, she has decided to stop buying food wrapped in plastic.
Her friend thinks that this will make no difference to the problem because the food has already been packaged and the plastic will end up in the environment anyway.
How could Amara’s action help lead to a reduction in the amount of microplastics in the environment?
Microplastics are a serious threat to marine organisms.
This problem needs a solution so that marine organisms are not further threatened.
Are the following strategies possible ways to reduce the amount of microplastics in marine environments?
Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each statement.
filtration of waste water before disposal
direct removal of microplastics from the seabed
increased recycling and reuse of existing plastic materials
advertising campaigns focusing on the use of sustainable energy sources to make plastics
